availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Urbin E. Ewing (Louisville, Jefferson County, Kentucky, physician.)

body.p: Louisville, Jefferson County, Kentucky, physician. Kentucky native. Married to Sarah Lloyd Robert Moore Ewing. Father of Catherine Moore Ewing, Robert Moore Ewing, Mary Lloyd Moore Ewing, Sallie Lloyd Moore Ewing, and John Donaldson Ewing. Married to Jane Butler Ewing. Father of Mildred Ewing, Nelly Ewing, and Jane Ewing. Resident of Louisville, Jefferson County, Kentucky, in 1840. Owned five enslaved persons in Louisville in 1840. Physician in Louisville in 1850. Owned seven enslaved persons in Louisville in 1850. Owned Joseph [Unknown] in Louisville in 1856. Owned Sam [Unknown] in Louisville in 1859. Physician in Louisville in 1860. Owned seven enslaved persons in Louisville in 1860. Employed Elizabeth Brown and Susan Collins as servants in Louisville in 1860.

Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Jefferson County, Louisville District 2, p. 193A.
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Jefferson County, Louisville District 2.

Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Jefferson County, Louisville Ward 3, p. 263A.
Ninth Manuscript Census of the United States (1870), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Jefferson County, Louisville Ward 7, p. 36A.
Kentucky Birth, Marriage and Death Records (1852-1910), KDLA, Frankfort, KY, Roll 994041, Jefferson County Deaths.
"A Negro Shoots at a Barber," Louisville Daily Courier (Louisville, KY), May 26, 1859, p. 1.
"Noted Woman," The Courier-Journal (Louisville, KY), May 21, 1907, p. 3.
Lineage Book: National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution, vol. II (Harrisburg, PA: The Harrisburg Publishing Company, 1896), 11-12.
